summary: On February 13, 2020, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Georgia entered a final judgment against Val Sklarov, a Georgia resident, and four entities he controls, for violating the registration provisions of the federal securities laws.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on August 6, 2019, in the Atlanta Regional Office, the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC alleges that, in violation of Section 15(a) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1, the registration provision of Sections 206(1) and 206(2) and that the defendants acted as an unregistered broker-dealer and did not exercise personal jurisdiction over any of the entities.  In addition, the complaint alleges that defendants used different corporations with the name "Bentley Rothschild Capital Limited" in connection with their business in Georgia, including Bentley Rothschild Capital LLC, Bentley Rothschild Financial LLC, America 2030 Capital Limited, and Black Rock Capital LLC.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, defendants consented to the entry of judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the federal registration provisions, and ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement of $1,038,078, plus prejudgment interest of $2,065, and a civil penalty of $100,000.   The settlement is subject to court approval. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can also use theÂ SECÂ instant.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a related matter, the SEC also issued an Investor Alert on January 12, 2019 that falsely claimed that the SEC had jurisdiction over all of the defendants in Georgia.  On January 13, 2019 the SEC filed a Complaint against the defendants, charging them with violations of the Exchange Act and Rule 15a-1 thereunder, as well as violations of Section 17(a)(1) of The Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act").  The Complaint also charged the defendants with violating Section 13(b)(2)(A) and 13(c) of Securities Exchange Rules 12b-20, 13a-13, and 13b-14 thereunder and with violating Exchange Act Section 10-b(5) and Rule 13d-1. The SEC's investigation was conducted by John R. Rymas and supervised by Jennifer C. McKinley of the Atlanta office. The litigation will be led by
